HUB Telematics Policy and Procedures

 

Employees operate company-owned vehicles on behalf of the company and drive more than XX miles each year. [Insert Company Name] commitment to high way safety and employee welfare, as well as the well being of the general public, is a top priority and the genesis of [Insert Company Name]. 

 

[Insert Telematics Vendor] is a satellite tracking system that is attached to the company vehicle, which monitors the vehicle during operation. This system monitors:

 

  • Speed of travel
  • Time of arrival
  • Length of stop
  • Time vehicle is spent idling
  • Location of the vehicle at every stop
  • Seat Belt Use
  • Vehicle Mileage
  • Acceleration and deceleration
  • Rapid starts – “jackrabbit starts”

 

All employees who drive vehicles in which a GPS/Telematics and/or ELD unit has been installed are expected to comply with all governmental statutes and regulations related to the operation of motor vehicles, and those employees will also be governed by specific[Insert Telematics Vendor] and [Insert Company Name] rules. These established rules are in addition to the [Insert Company Name] Fleet Safety Program and any applicable regulatory or government discipline, which may supersede this policy. 

 

Driving habits,patterns and violations of the policy are reviewed monthly and remain on the driver’s record for 12 months. This means that a [Insert Telematics Vendor]/ [Insert Company Name] policy violation remains viable and subject to progressive disciplinary actions for one year from the date of the violation. If multiple violations occur on the same day, they may be treated as one violation, with any applicable discipline based upon the most serious offense.

 

Company Vehicles Requiring a GPS Unit

All Company owned vehicles assigned to drivers are required to be equipped with a GPS unit.

 

Required Measures

The following GPS-related activities are required measures and may be appealed only under the guidelines of the paragraph entitled Appeals.All “Coaching” citations given to the employee must include the specific telematics report noting the violation. To ensure [Insert Company Name] provides a thorough review of potential violations we are providing the following list of potential violations. 

 

Telematics and Driving Violations include: 

 

  1. Vehicles that travel 71 mph up to 79 mph:
    1. First offense will be a written warning.
    2. Second offense results in a final written warning.
    3. Third violation will result in termination.

 

  1. Vehicles that travel 80 mph up to 89 mph:
    1. First offense will be a written warning.
    2. Second offense will result in termination.

 

  1. Vehicles that travel 90 mph and greater:
    1. Immediate termination.

 

  1. Vehicles left idling at any service location:
    1. First offense will be a written warning.
    2. Second offense will result in termination.

 

  1. Failure to wear seat belt while driving Company vehicle:
    1. First Offense will result in written warning.
    2. Second offense will result in final warning.
    3. Third offense will result in termination.

 

  1. Stops that deviate from the Specialist’s (Technician’s) assigned route of service or other unscheduled stops, which cause the route to be run out of sequenceor cause customersto be serviced outside their time window:
    1. First offense will result in a written warning.
    2. Second offense will result in termination.

 

  1. Unauthorized use of company vehicle after work hours:
    1. First offense will result in written warning.
    2. Second offense will result in final warning.
    3. Third offense will result in termination.

 

  1. Tampering with the GPS unit:
    1. First offense will result in written warning. 
    2. Second offense will result in termination.

 

  1. Specialist (Technician) provides service to non-Company customer:
    1. First offense will result in termination.

 

NOTE: The Company reserves the right, if the Manager and Human Resources Manager finds the employee’s driving to be careless, reckless, or otherwise dangerous based on the road conditions or area in which the violation occurred, to terminate an employee even if the employee has not exhausted all disciplinary measures leading up to termination.

 

Delegating Responsibility

The Manager will have the ultimate responsibility for enforcing the company policy. The Manager may delegate responsibility for managing the policy to other managers or team members.  [Insert Company Name] will conduct periodic, unannounced audits to ensure compliance.

 

Risk Management provides a monthly violation report to each office/driver, which outlines all the violations for that month that require corrective action. It is the Manager’s responsibility to ensure the Coaching form is completed and a copy is sent to Risk Management.

 

Each location must maintain the following:

 

  • 1 to 31-day binder containing the “Risk Management Reports”
  • “Trips List Reports”, if violations are listed
  • Copies of the “Coaching” forms, when disciplinary measures were delivered

 

Appeals 

Appeals of any GPS-related disciplinary actions may be considered by a panel in Risk Management and may be requested only under extenuating circumstances. While an investigation of the driver’s record is being conducted, the temporary suspension of operating company vehicles should be enforced.Human Resources and Risk Management will review each situation on an individual basis with a prompt decision being made regarding the employment status.

 

The following are the extenuating circumstances that could prompt an appeal to any GPS-related disciplinary actions.

 

  • Medical emergency.
  • When specifically requested by law enforcement officer or some similar governmental official to engage in the behavior which violates the policy.
  • Where an individual’s supervisor has amended the assigned route of service for business-related purposes.
  • Technical malfunction.

 

[Insert Company Name] may require operation of the vehicle at or under the posted speed limit. A violation of speed of travel under these conditions does not constitute a reason for appeal.

 

Compliance Procedures

The Manager is responsible for enforcing and administering the disciplinary measures associated with violations of the GPS policy. The required “remedial training forms” must be completed and filed in the employee’s personnel file in the office, and a copy emailed to Risk Management office.

 

GPS Equipment Repairs

 

  • All new GPS equipment is covered under a warranty.
  • If any of the GPS equipment requires repair during the warranty period, contact Risk Management at 1. XXX.XXX.XXXX
  • Risk Management will coordinate the equipment repairs with the vendor.
  • Risk Management will maintain a small supply of emergency equipment, which may be loaned to locations that must have immediate replacement.
  • Once the warranty period is over, the locations will be charged for GPS equipment repairs.

 

 

COACHING FORM

                                                                                                               

Your driving performance has been measured by the [Insert Telematics Vendor] and recorded as inappropriate based on the company telematics policy. (Manager: List infraction and attach the applicable GPS report(s). Be sure to note specific dates, times, locations and other specific information that applies to the violation.)

 

Acceptable conduct/ performance is that no additional infractions occur for a period of one year.Further violations of the [Insert Company Name] Telematics Policy and/or any regulatory or government regulations may result in further disciplinary measures, up to and including termination.

 

  • I agree to comply with all Rules of the Road, as outlined in the Global Positioning System guidelines and policy.
  • I agree to obey all government and regulatory agency laws and rules specific to my driving conduct.
  • I agree to adhere to the Company Driver Certification Policy.
  • I will complete a Defensive Driving Course within 30 days of this warning,if I have not already completed such a course.

 

Note: Employee’s signature on this form indicates that this situation has been discussed. It does not necessarily mean the employee agrees. Send copy to Risk Management and retain a copy of this form in the employee’s personnel file.

GPS RULES OF THE ROAD NOTIFICATION OF TERMINATION

 

   

Your driving performance has been measured by the [Insert Telematics Vendor] and recorded as inappropriate based on the [Insert Company Name] Policy. (Manager: List infraction and attach the applicable GPS report(s). Be sure to note specific dates, times, locations and other specific information that applies to the violation.)

 

Based upon the violation(s) of Company Policy listed above, your employment is terminated, effectively immediately.

 

Note: Employee’s signature on this form indicates that this situation has been discussed. It does not necessarily mean the employee agrees. Send copy to Risk Management and retain a copy of this form in the employee’s personnel file.

 

ALTERING, TAMPERING OR DISCONNECTING VEHICLE RECORDING AND MONITORING DEVICES

 

As an authorized driver of [Insert Company Name], you have been given certain privileges and responsibilities when operating your company vehicle. Company drivers are required to check vehicle equipment before and after shifts to ensure the vehicle is functioning properly. If any piece of equipment is found to be not operational or disconnected, the Vehicle Condition Report (VCR) should be noted and reported to management immediately. Furthermore, employees shall not engage in the following practices:

 

 

  • Employees shall not disconnect cameras, recording devices or telematics systems from the vehicle.

 

  • Employees shall not alter driver logs or electronic monitoring devices from the vehicle. 

 

Failure to comply with any of these responsibilities will result in immediate termination. There is a ZERO TOLERANCE POLICY as it pertains to the disconnecting of cameras, telematics and/or recording devices installed on the company vehicles. 

 

Each driver is responsible for the actual possession, care and use of the company vehicle in their possession. Therefore, a driver’s responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following:

 

  • Operation of the vehicle in a manner consistent with reasonable practices that avoid abuse, theft, neglect or disrespect of the equipment.

 

  • Obey all traffic laws.

 

  • The use of seat belts and shoulder harness is mandatory for driver and passengers.

 

  • Adhering to manufacturer’s recommendations regarding service, maintenance and inspection. Vehicles should not be operated with any defect that would prevent safe operation.

 

  • Attention to and practice of safe driving techniques and adherence to current safety requirements.

 

  • Restricting the use of vehicles to authorized driver, spouse or significant other.

 

  • Reporting the occurrence of moving violations within 24 hours.

 

  • Accurate, comprehensive and timely reporting of all accidents by an authorized driver and thefts of a company vehicle to the company Fleet Safety Manager.

 

 

I have read and will abide by the conditions as stated in this document regarding the operation of any vehicle for company business.

 

Note: Employee’s signature on this form indicates that this situation has been discussed. It does not necessarily mean the employee agrees. Send copy to Risk Management and retain a copy of this form in the employee’s personnel file. Failure to comply with any of these responsibilities will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.
